Beat me too it :-)

interface MyNetworkInterface {

// all method that I'm currently interested in using.

public void wrappedStaticMethod() ;
}

public class MyNetworkInterfaceImpl implements MyNetworkInterface {

public void wrappedStaticMethod() {
NetworkInterface.staticMethod() ;
}

}



public class MockMyNetworkInterfaceImpl implements MyNetworkInterface {

public void wrappedStaticMethod() {
wasWrappedStaticMethod= true;
}

public boolean wasWrappedStaticMethodCalled() {
return wasWrappedStaticMethod;
}

private boolean wasWrappedStaticMethod;
}



It does mean you 'lose' the simplicity of the production code just
calling a static method in line, as it now has to instantiate an
MyNetworkInterfaceImpl object to call its instance method
'wrappedStaticMethod()'. However, the benefit of it now being
substitutable, outweighs this.

I find this pattern (Replace static call with instance call) very useful
in aiding testability and general substitutability.
